content:
"Chopsticks" and "Waltz in D-flat major" are actually the same piece, but with different names.

"Chopsticks" is the popular nickname for the piece, which was given to it because of the way the right-hand melody sounds like a series of "chopping" or "staccato" notes. This name was likely coined by the public, rather than the composer herself.

The official title of the piece is "Waltz in D-flat major," which was written by Euphemia Allen in 1877. The waltz is a type of dance that originated in Europe in the 16th century, characterized by a strong emphasis on the first beat of each measure and a lilting, swaying rhythm. The Waltz in D-flat major is a classic example of this style, with a beautiful, flowing melody and a strong rhythmic pulse.

So, while "Chopsticks" is the more commonly used name, "Waltz in D-flat major" is the official title of the piece. Both names refer to the same beautiful and iconic piano composition!

It's worth noting that the piece was originally published as "The Celebrated Chop Waltz" in 1877, which may have contributed to the confusion. Over time, the nickname "Chopsticks" became more widely used, while the original title "Waltz in D-flat major" was often forgotten.
